message: Hi Avery, it's great to meet you! I was really intrigued by your research work at Redwood State, especially the part about protecting models from data exploitation. Could you tell me a bit about what drew you into that problem space?

Yeah, absolutely. I think I just kept noticing that a lot of work focused on making models better, faster, more accurate, but not necessarily safer. I kind of fell into a few papers around model inversion and data leakage, and it felt like an area where small ideas could have meaningful impact. So I explored it further and it turned into a pretty serious research direction.

That's a really thoughtful way to approach it. I also saw you implemented a defense method with diffusion autoencoders in PyTorch. What was the most challenging part of turning that idea into something that actually worked on large datasets?

Honestly, getting it to scale without breaking the assumptions behind the method. On paper it sounded straightforward, but once you start pushing 100k-plus samples through it, edge cases show up. A lot of time went into figuring out where the model was quietly failing rather than loudly failing.

That makes sense. Switching gears a bit, your experience at BluePeak shows strong data engineering alongside ML. How did working on large ETL pipelines influence the way you approach ML system design today?

I think it made me more cautious, in a good way. You start realizing models are only as good as the pipelines feeding them. So now I tend to think about data flow, monitoring, and failure modes almost before I think about model architecture.

I really like that perspective. One more thing I'm curious aboutâ€”your sentiment model at RetailPulse had a pretty tangible business impact. How did you balance model experimentation with the need to ship something reliable in production?

We tried not to over-optimize for cleverness. There were a few fancier approaches we tested, but the BERT-based pipeline was the one we understood well enough to trust in production. It wasn't necessarily the most novel, just the most dependable under constraints.
